source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: Maine Yankee fuel showed that deleterious interactions between the fuel pellet and Zircaloy cladding did not have to follow large or rapid power changes; they could also occur in the low-stress (strain) but highly corrosive (from fission product) conditions

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: SCC might be the dominant fracture mode for Zircaloy cladding in the variety of PCI events that could occur during normal and off-normal (as typified by test reactor ramps to ~60 kW/m at ~100 kW/m/min ramp rates) conditions

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: test reactor ramps to ~60 kW/m at ~100 kW/m/min ramp rates

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: cladding cracks (possessing many if not all of the SCC features) were located in fuel rods that were subjected to power ramps from ~30 to ~42 kW/m after a local burn-up of 14 000 MWD/tons of uranium (Dresden 3)

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: power ramps from ~20 to ~30 kW/m after burn-ups of 10 000 to 13 000 MWD/tons of uranium (Oskarshamn 1)

evidence_span: power ramps from ~17 to ~20 kW/m after burn-ups of 10 000 to 13 000 MWD/tons of uranium (Oskarshamn 1)

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: power ramps from ~25 to ~28 kW/m after burn-ups of ~10 000 MWD/tons of uranium (Maine Yankee)

evidence_span: power increment range of 6 to 20 kW/m to 20 to 35 kW/m

evidence_span: Our data indicate some advantage of coldworked stress-relieved over fully recrystallized Zircaloy with respect to SCC threshold and time to failure

evidence_span: Our data indicate some advantage of coldworked stress-relieved over fully recrystallized Zircaloy with respect to SCC threshold and time to failure

evidence_span: a large grain size fuel pellet is fabricated using niobium oxide (Nb₂O₃) dopant; the large grains result in longer diffusion paths for fission gas bubbles and hence delay the grain boundary saturation that initiates the release mechanism

evidence_span: the outer region is enriched uranium, while the inner core is natural uranium; for the same rod power, the average fuel temperature is lower and the temperature gradient is flatter

evidence_span: copper (plated on the inner surface) and zirconium (coextruded with the Zircaloy)

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: The data points represent fractional channel closure at the ninety-fifth percentile for the worst axial grid span versus region (or assembly) average burn-up.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: The bow recorded in the few Babcock and Wilcox (BW), Combustion Engineering (CE), and Exxon Nuclear Co. (ENC) assemblies is insignificant

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: the maximum bow observed in the Westinghouse (W) fuel, although significant, is well below the National Research Council's (NRC) design limits

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: Test rods containing four different types of Zircaloy 4 cladding had been inserted into two normally standard $1 5 \times 1 5$ assemblies

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: cladding types ranged from cold-worked, stress-relieved (CWSR) at $\mathbf { 7 1 3 ~ K }$ EMPY $( 9 0 5 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } )$ (designated S1), through CWSR ${ \bf 8 2 7 ~ K }$ $( 1 0 0 4 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } )$ (V1) and CWSR $8 4 7 ~ \mathrm { K }$ $( 1 0 4 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F } )$ (V2), to recrystallized $8 6 9 ~ \mathrm { K }$ $( 1 0 8 0 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { F } )$ (S2)

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: The cold-worked, stressrelieved cladding provided the greatest resistance to large bows

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: the S2 cladding exhibited bow in the 1.1 to $1 . 3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ (45 to $5 0 \ \mathrm { m i l } )$ range

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: the S1, V1, and V2 cladding had no segments in excess of $1 \ m \mathrm { m }$ $( 4 0 \ \mathrm { m i l } )$ EPY bow

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: measured rod growth from different PWR (Zircaloy-4) and BWR (Zircaloy-2) assemblies is similar and appears to follow a similar relationship

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: Rod growth falls below the stress-free growth curve

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: With the unstable pellet (namely, densifying), significant creepdown and ovalization occurred, resulting in only point contact between fuel and cladding even after ~26 000 MWD/tons of uranium burn-up

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: By far the largest creepdown and ovalization was measured in the hard S1 cladding; S2 exhibited the least amounts of creepdown and ovality

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: with a highly stable experimental fuel pellet, creepdown and ovality were inhibited by early fuel-cladding contact

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: At 631 K $( 6 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { F } )$ , S1 showed the highest burst strength, ultimate tensile strength, and retained ductility, whereas S2 showed the lowest values for these properties
property_name: burst strength, ultimate tensile strength, retained ductility

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Zircaloys do oxidize under the reactor coolant conditions of BWRs and PWRs

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: thin uniform cohesive layer 1 to $1 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ thick that will not exceed $\sim 1 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ , even after ten years' exposure

evidence_span: increased uniform oxidation that starts to spall at $\gtrsim 7 0 - \mu \mathrm { m }$ thickness

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk6

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_005_chunk6
